results.title: Tom Phillips
results.creator_credit: David Rowan, Margaret Williams, Arbor Films and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Covers many aspects of Tom Phillips’ work which includes painting, drawing, graphics and music. Features commentary by Phillips about his two collage works “Humument” and “Benches” providing a fascinating insight into the mind of this original and creative artist.

results.title: Tom Cruise as Ironman - Deepfake Theater

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

results.description: Years after the release of Iron Man in 2008, rumours persisted that Tom Cruise had been set to play Tony Stark, the role immortalised by Robert Downey Jr., in the 2008 blockbuster directed by Jon Favreau. In August 2019, Deepfake Theater couldn’t resist the urge to ‘magic up’ an alternate version of Iron Man’s trajectory through the Marvel Cinematic Universe in a video that employed deepfake technology to superimpose Cruise over scenes shot with Robert Downey Jr. across the gamut of Marvel Studios’ back catalogue.
description_for_label: Years after the release of Iron Man in 2008, rumours persisted that Tom Cruise had been set to play Tony Stark, the role immortalised by Robert Downey Jr., in the 2008 blockbuster directed by Jon Favreau. results.title: Tolstoy after Anna Karenina
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
After publishing Anna Karenina Tolstoy suffered a crisis in his personal and public life. The question which in Anna Karenina haunts Levin “Why am I?” became more and more urgent to Tolstoy and his answers became more extreme. He was a man who craved solitude, but his admirers almost made this impossible for him. Tolstoy died on 7 November 1910. Documentary also features Russian writers Godky and Chekov. Uses archival footage and stills.

results.title: Toller
results.creator_credit: John Watson, Pen Densham and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Hailed as “the world’s most exciting and innovative figure skater”. Canadian, Toller Cranston, is the subject of this film. Apart from being a brilliant ice skater, Cranston is also an accomplished fine artist with numerous painting exhibitions to his credit. The film shows several skating routines in full, depicting Toller’s original style and how sometimes he uses some of his painting ideas in his skating routines. Features the World Championships at Colorado Springs.

results.title: Tokyo industrial worker
results.brief_description: Aside from serving as the nation’s capital, Tokyo is an industrial centre that boasts the manufacture of virtually every conceivable type of product. It also faces such typical urban problems as pollution and overcrowding, as well as its unique and chaotic system of unnumbered streets. This film is about the O-ga family who live in one of Tokyo’s immediate suburbs. It follows the family’s routine on a typical weekday including Mr O-ga motorbiking his way to the small factory where he is employed as a draftsman-technician. Like Mr O-ga, thousands of Japanese are heading for Tokyo and its environs, creating a massive commuter crush. At six o’clock, the work day ends. Mr O-ga returns to his modest home, the evening meal served Japanese-fashion at a low table, and television. Although many western influences are clearly visible in Tokyo, its people have not relinquished their most favoured traditions.

results.title: Toil and trouble
results.brief_description: When the warehouse boss lowers the overheads, Bronwen fights back and earns a black belt in Industrial Relations. Produced in the style of the silent era, and performed in mime, this short story also contains a social political message of today’s IR laws in Australia. Music soundtrack with English intertitles. Music by Donna Coleman (pianist), Disasteradio and The Raskolnikovs. Warning: contains coarse language.
